page.title: 16THE PUBS IN THE AREA 4
page.content: 'The Station' derives its name from the the former adjacent Horsehay railway station. This was closed in the early sixties, though some of the rail tracks still remain and a steam trust has been set-up with the aim of restoring the station and running a steam train service to the former next station south at Lightmoor, about 2km away. The 'All Labour in Vain', has an unusual pub sign, with a little black boy being scrubbed clean. The origins of this sign are unknown, though it may have something to do with the former mining community and the ritual of the miner's bath. The pub was once 'John Bull's' local (See William Ball). Now it is famous for its food and snacks; one is just as likely to meet a Japanese employee from Maxell or a visiting European businesssman
